summary: One of my most vivid memories of highschool is when I was in math class and the teacher asked a question (the answer was...
body: One of my most vivid memories of highschool is when I was in math class and the teacher asked a question (the answer was polygon) so I was like oh I know the answer! I yell out porygon (the name of a Pokémon) I’ve never been more embarrassed thank goodness nobody in the class knew what I was saying.

blog.name: weirdandwackypokefusions
blog.title: Well that's strange!
blog.description:
Welcome!  I create, using the all-mighty classic Microsoft XP Paint, my own pokemon fusions. All the sprites come from pokestadium and usually people on deviantart/ the xy/sun&moon sprite project. I don't own any of the sprite used, I just fuse them! 
REQUESTS ARE OPEN! Ask Box: 3/15.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO DRAW MY FUSIONS!!  I absolutely love it when people draw them! There's no need to ask either! Just make sure you tag me so them I can see it!
I hope you enjoy my fusions!

summary: Slurty Slurpuff and Skitty fusion Normal/Fairy type Ability: Ice Body The Neapolitan Pokemon Slurty is made from ice-cream and...
caption:
Slurty

Slurpuff and Skitty fusion

Normal/Fairy type

Ability: Ice Body

The Neapolitan Pokemon

Slurty is made from ice-cream and melts in the sun. It needs to be kept in cool temperatures for it to move around.  It loves to give hugs, although it is very cold to touch. It smells just like chocolate, vanilla and strawberry. 

Request for @k-jeopardy. I hope you like it! The colours reminded me of ice cream.

blog.name: notnormalmydude
blog.title: Pokemon Sun, Moon and Violence
blog.description: Insanity the likes of which Alola has never seen

summary: A critically thinking Baloo is a dangerous Baloo --------------------------------------------------------------- Pint: Baloo!...
caption:
A critically thinking Baloo is a dangerous Baloo

—————————————————————

Pint: Baloo!
Baloo: Pint, what do you feel?
Pint: The wealth of negative emotion off the Keldeo and somewhere nearby someone is managing to outmatch it
Baloo: Had a feeling… Keldeo don’t raid cave dwellers’ nests… If this had been Ribombee’s nest then I’d understand

Pint: What are you thinking..?
Baloo: I’m sure we’re being watched right now. The Keldeo is moving too erratically like its following a drill so chances are the trainer isn’t close enough to be heard. If so I would’ve heard them too
Pint: True… The Jangmo'o weren’t acting oddly like they do when people wander close. Their scent must be masked or its too light to be picked up
Baloo: Mhm… Then I’m going to have to rely on other senses…


Baloo: I can’t see… I can’t smell… These caves are about to get dark so even if I had a glimpse it would do nothing. Ok… Remember to listen and feel. If I can get a hold of them for even a second I might have enough scent to follow…

But how..? I need noise, its quiet in here… There has to be something I can do…

!!! Sammy and Talbain! Of course. That’ll work, now to make it inconspicuous… If that Keldeo gets a hold of Talbain it’ll be bad

blog.name: inikavulpixelreviews
blog.title: Let's Talk About Pokemon!
blog.description:
Reviewing my personal opinion on every single Pokemon! Yes, all 809 of them!
(Mostly) Daily Uploads, 3 PM EST.

summary: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Gen 5 Retrospective
title: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Gen 5 Retrospective
body:
While Gen 2 might’ve gotten pretty warm reception, Gens 3 and 4 were not as fortunate. They may have a good share of fans these days but I remember at least a VERY vocal minority talking up how much they disliked the direction Pokemon was going design-wise. Common criticism being that the designs looked too artificial, Pokemon are often overdesigned, and the new art direction was a downturn for people. Not that there’s anything wrong with that of course, you do you and all that. The first two points I actually somewhat agree with though it’s never been enough to ruin those gens for me.

Then Gen 5 happened when opinions on Pokemon were at what seemed like an all-time low post-Diamond and Pearl. Oof.

Sadly, when Gen 5 dropped, those feelings of resentment toward the Pokemon designs only sky-rocketed, as it released some of the Pokemon with the most ire drawn toward them out of all Pokemon in the entire franchise. Combined with that was the overall soft reboot approach Gen 5 had for designing Pokemon. Common criticism was that Pokemon like Woobat, Roggenrola, or Audino were inherently uncreative for being rehashes of already well-established Pokemon.

And I couldn’t disagree more, of course. If anything I love how this generation ties so closely with Gen 1. It does so lovingly but not at all does it ever come off as pandering. It really shows how, as much as things stay the same, things have also changed in Pokemon. They bring some neat spins on familiar concepts, like Swoobat, Foongus, and Garbodor. But they also bring plenty of fresh taste to the table in Zoroark, Vanilluxe, and Escavalier and such.

A lot of the Gen 5 disdain seems to come from a handful of Pokemon, comparatively. Most common dislikes I see are Garbodor, Vanilluxe, and Stunfisk, toted as signs Gamefreak was “running out of ideas.” Bah, I’ve gone on this rant multiple times, on each of these families’ reviews, so I’ll spare it this time. Tl;dr, I still fail to see how living garbage and ice cream and a flatfish whoopie-cushion-mine are bad bases for creatures. They’re no less valid that living sludge and magnets! And again, I’d have to see a generation of mostly dogs, cats, mice, and foxes imbued with different elemental powers before I’d ever say Gamefreak was running out of ideas.

With keeping in mind how Gen 4 might’ve been the end, if not for the series, then for that particular era of Pokemon, Gen 5 was an absolutely brilliant way to re-introduce everything. It really was a turning point, feeling like now that they’ve gotten a lot of leftovers done and out of the way in Gen 4, they could start completely fresh in Gen 5 and make ideas that are entirely new for Pokemon. While Gen 4 may have suffered in the creativity department a little bit, the post-Gen 4 world of Pokemon is still moving strong to this day. There was definitely some internal re-thinking of the Pokemon design philosophy going on when they were making Gen 5 in one way or another. And whatever it is, it’s clearly working, as each Gen from 5-onwards has been consistently strong in the Pokemon-design department.

Even artistically, Gen 5 has a lot of polish and care behind it compared to maybe Gen 3 or 4, which had a tendency to put one detail too many into a design. That’s not been so prevalent in Gen 5, barring perhaps Legendaries and maybe a tiny handful of others. Designs are even opting to be a lot more personality driven. Of course not meaning that to say Gens 1-4 don’t have personality, but Gen 5 is a lot more expressive about it.

And if anything, Gen 5 is an ending just as much as it is a new beginning. This is the last we’ll see of the 2D style of main series Pokemon game. It appropriately feels like a wrap-up to have one last revisit to older ideas. Gen 1, one more time before moving onto the 3DS. It also works for well expanding Pokemon’s biodiversity in the game before Gen 6 and 7, where the creatures are considerably more wacky and out-there.

Either way, Gen 5 has a closeness to my heart in general. It introduced so many favorites, including TOP favorites, let alone my favorite Pokemon of all time at the forefront of the game’s unveiling. This was also the first time I got to sit through the hype season of a Pokemon game. Anticipating the coro-coro leaks every months whilst waking up every morning refreshing Serebii like a maniac, just eagerly awaiting to see what the new Pokemon would look like. That was a fun time, indeed. The only thing that would’ve made it better would be if I got to tackle the game blind other than what was officially revealed. But even then, this also marked the first time Pokemon had an engaging story and some actually really well developed characters. They were all ingredients for my favorite Generation to date, at least Pokemon-wise. The games and their story themselves are in tight competition with Sun and Moon, but that’s for a later date.

Top 10 Favorites of Gen 5:

Damn that’s some stiff competition. And if I’m not mistaken, the first time we have a full house of 10 outta 10ers here. You SEE what Gen 5 has done to me?! Of course, there’s Zorua. My favorite Pokemon of all time and everything, with Zoroark not far behind. Gen 5 managed to pick on some crazy niches of mine, even down to something as specific as a dessert monster! For real though, all of these Pokemon are lovely and near perfect.

The Top 10 Just Under the Top 10 of Gen 5:

Because DAMMIT there’s so many good ones I can’t pick just 10.

Top 10 Favorites Overall:

…Though I feel like the impact it’s made on my top favorites may be a little deceptive, even if Zorua has finally toppled the champion four Generations in a row, Vulpix. If we were to look at more of a top 50 up to Gen 5, these newcomer faves would’ve had an absolute takeover.

Bottom 10 Least Favorites:

Gotta compress the monkeys and genies into one spot… cause they’d pretty much take up the entire Bottom 10. And even then, I think it says something when only half of these I’m not a very big fan of, and the other half are at least passable to kinda liking to me.

Bottom 10 Least Favorites Overall:

So they’ll make the slightest of dents here instead. And I’ll just lump them together since I mostly dislike them as collectives anyway.

The Cutest:

Pretty much all of these are gonna be some stiff competition and I’m slaying myself to come to a conclusion to. That said though, there’s no way Sewaddle and Joltik couldn’t have made it here. Just LOOK AT THEM.

The Coolest:

If some kick-ass monsters are what you’re after, I feel like Gen 5 definitely doesn’t get enough credit here. Again, it pains me to leave some out, like Genesect, Scolipede, Gigalith, and Archeops.

The Prettiest:

Wow, a whole house of pretty Pokemon too? Nice.

The Spookiest:

A good generation for spooks too! It sadly may not have the hugest variety but what is there is Halloweeny as hell and I love it. Even got an alien! Aliens are 200% underrated as Halloween monsters.

Most Creative:

God Gen 5 has so many Pokemon with fun and cool nuances to their designs. Scrafty to me is still a level of clever that comes pretty close to rivaling Shedinja.

Weirdest/Most Unique:

I even could’ve stuck quite a few I’ve already picked from above, like Beheeyem or Escavalier in here too. But fully and truly, Cryogonal is one weird as hell Pokemon. There’s actually nothing else like it in the game, I feel. What Pokemon fan would’ve asked for an ominously floating snowflake face that also turns out to be carnivorous??? It’s great.

Most Forgettable:

Yeah, mostly the common, early-game fodder Pokemon this time around. Especially since to one extent or another, their previous forms appeal to me just a little bit more.

Most Under-Appreciated:

Pshhhh, yeah, I’m sure Garbodor and Vanilluxe could be seen from a mile away. And yeah, by now they’ve developed their own niche of fans. But I still see them a lot, if not in the videos themselves, in the thumbnails of “Top 10 Worst/Least Creative Pokemon Designs” videos from Youtubers. (But we’ll let creatively bankrupt Gallade slide I guess)

And I’ll donate the rest of the space to Pokemon that just need to be noticed in general.

Summing up Gen 5 in 6 Pokemon:

God, that’s a tough one and you KNOW it, me. But I ultimately decided upon this. As big a variety of monsters as I could think of. Mainly because Gen 5’s sense of variety is insane. Probably at least partly due to there being so many, but still. There’s a Pokemon of all sorts of flavors, and many Pokemon for each flavor. Everybody, no matter what, should be able to find a handful to like in Gen 5. Even if you think Garbodor ruins the entire Generation on its own.

My Gen 5 Team:

Hoo boy, prepare yourselves cause this is the game I’ve easily replayed all the way through the most. But I’ll just cover the major playthroughs I did.

Shortly after the games launched in Japan, like a naughty person I… downloaded and played a ROM of it before the games were even out in the US. I was too friggin excited to play it! But here I kinda deliberately picked some Pokemon I didn’t think I’d be big on using in the main game so I could save the good stuff for when I play it for real. Including my least favorite Starter, obviously. I didn’t expect Leavanny and Krookodile to kick so much ass though.

And here is when I started to pick up my current mantra when it comes to picking out the team I’d like to use for a playthrough of a Pokemon game. I’ll pick out a handful I’ll like, (And if it’s the first playthrough of a new Generation, I’ll pick only new Pokemon. Not that it was difficult in the Generation with no old ones in it, of course, but Black and White inspired that rule.) and I’ll choose at least one Pokemon that’s unassuming and I wouldn’t be sure is good or not. It was Unfezant. Needless to say, bad stats and movepool matchup lead to it swiftly getting replaced by Zekrom as soon as the game asked me to. Heatmor’s still low-tier enough to consider it the unassuming pick right…?

But for real, this right here is probably one of my most memorable teams through a game to date. Unfezant aside, just about everyone kicked ass and took names. Gigalith especially. My Bertha wrecks house and I love her.

And then there’s my team for White 2. My unassuming Pokemon was Magnemite, but then it turned out Magnezone actually kicks a lot of ass. Probably partly what led to me falling in love with the thing.

Most Long Overdue Concepts and Creatures:

Galvantula’s on here just because it’s A. While not the first spider, the first spider that actually looks like a Spider. And B. While not the first spider, the first spider since Gen 2. You’d think spiders would be a much more common appearance in Pokemon!! Also missing was an ant Pokemon, Centipedes, Hermit Crabs, and flatfish. And a multi-headed dragon. Surprised we didn’t get one of those before.

Best Pokemon as Gen 1 Parallels:

Many of the Pokemon this Gen seeked out to recapture Gen 1’s magic touch, to a point where that was a deliberation outright stated in an interview about the game. I feel like this batch of 6 (7) do it best, in that they are a clear reference to previous Pokemon, but have enough of their own merit to stand on their own as well. Swoobat is almost like an anti-Golbat, Genesect is a cool way to “remake” Mewtwo, Sawk and Throh are Hitmonlee and Hitmonchan but a little more visually tied together. Garbodor is more or less the Muk of the Generation, representing physical waste vs water pollution. And Musharna is just a good example of how you can take something as specific as a dream-eating tapir and put different spins on it. Fun!

…Okay I’m bsing categories at this point just to make it last that tiny bit longer, sorry.

And… it saddens me a little bit, but that’s all that’s left to say about Gen 5. A fantastic Generation that’s gonna be really hard for a future Gen to top for me. None so far has done it yet, and of course we’ll have to wait and see if the rumblings of Gen 8 will triumph. But I digress, fret not! Not all is bad, because Gen 6 and 7 both give Gen 5 a fair amount of competition here. Next time, after the usual break, we’re KINDA gonna move into Gen 6. But we’ve got something else to cover briefly before we start Gen 6 for real.

[Archive]

Common criticism being that the designs looked too artificial, Pokemon are often overdesigned, and the new art direction was a downturn for people. Not that there’s anything wrong with that of course, you do you and all that. The first two points I actually somewhat agree with though it’s never been enough to ruin those gens for me.

Then Gen 5 happened when opinions on Pokemon were at what seemed like an all-time low post-Diamond and Pearl. Oof.

Sadly, when Gen 5 dropped, those feelings of resentment toward the Pokemon designs only sky-rocketed, as it released some of the Pokemon with the most ire drawn toward them out of all Pokemon in the entire franchise. Combined with that was the overall soft reboot approach Gen 5 had for designing Pokemon. Common criticism was that Pokemon like Woobat, Roggenrola, or Audino were inherently uncreative for being rehashes of already well-established Pokemon.

And I couldn’t disagree more, of course. If anything I love how this generation ties so closely with Gen 1. It does so lovingly but not at all does it ever come off as pandering. It really shows how, as much as things stay the same, things have also changed in Pokemon. They bring some neat spins on familiar concepts, like Swoobat, Foongus, and Garbodor. But they also bring plenty of fresh taste to the table in Zoroark, Vanilluxe, and Escavalier and such.

A lot of the Gen 5 disdain seems to come from a handful of Pokemon, comparatively. Most common dislikes I see are Garbodor, Vanilluxe, and Stunfisk, toted as signs Gamefreak was “running out of ideas.” Bah, I’ve gone on this rant multiple times, on each of these families’ reviews, so I’ll spare it this time. Tl;dr, I still fail to see how living garbage and ice cream and a flatfish whoopie-cushion-mine are bad bases for creatures. They’re no less valid that living sludge and magnets! And again, I’d have to see a generation of mostly dogs, cats, mice, and foxes imbued with different elemental powers before I’d ever say Gamefreak was running out of ideas.

With keeping in mind how Gen 4 might’ve been the end, if not for the series, then for that particular era of Pokemon, Gen 5 was an absolutely brilliant way to re-introduce everything. It really was a turning point, feeling like now that they’ve gotten a lot of leftovers done and out of the way in Gen 4, they could start completely fresh in Gen 5 and make ideas that are entirely new for Pokemon. While Gen 4 may have suffered in the creativity department a little bit, the post-Gen 4 world of Pokemon is still moving strong to this day. There was definitely some internal re-thinking of the Pokemon design philosophy going on when they were making Gen 5 in one way or another. And whatever it is, it’s clearly working, as each Gen from 5-onwards has been consistently strong in the Pokemon-design department.

Even artistically, Gen 5 has a lot of polish and care behind it compared to maybe Gen 3 or 4, which had a tendency to put one detail too many into a design. That’s not been so prevalent in Gen 5, barring perhaps Legendaries and maybe a tiny handful of others. Designs are even opting to be a lot more personality driven. Of course not meaning that to say Gens 1-4 don’t have personality, but Gen 5 is a lot more expressive about it.

And if anything, Gen 5 is an ending just as much as it is a new beginning. This is the last we’ll see of the 2D style of main series Pokemon game. It appropriately feels like a wrap-up to have one last revisit to older ideas. Gen 1, one more time before moving onto the 3DS. It also works for well expanding Pokemon’s biodiversity in the game before Gen 6 and 7, where the creatures are considerably more wacky and out-there.

Either way, Gen 5 has a closeness to my heart in general. It introduced so many favorites, including TOP favorites, let alone my favorite Pokemon of all time at the forefront of the game’s unveiling. This was also the first time I got to sit through the hype season of a Pokemon game. Anticipating the coro-coro leaks every months whilst waking up every morning refreshing Serebii like a maniac, just eagerly awaiting to see what the new Pokemon would look like. That was a fun time, indeed. The only thing that would’ve made it better would be if I got to tackle the game blind other than what was officially revealed. But even then, this also marked the first time Pokemon had an engaging story and some actually really well developed characters. They were all ingredients for my favorite Generation to date, at least Pokemon-wise. The games and their story themselves are in tight competition with Sun and Moon, but that’s for a later date.

Top 10 Favorites of Gen 5:

Damn that’s some stiff competition. And if I’m not mistaken, the first time we have a full house of 10 outta 10ers here. You SEE what Gen 5 has done to me?! Of course, there’s Zorua. My favorite Pokemon of all time and everything, with Zoroark not far behind. Gen 5 managed to pick on some crazy niches of mine, even down to something as specific as a dessert monster! For real though, all of these Pokemon are lovely and near perfect.

The Top 10 Just Under the Top 10 of Gen 5:

Because DAMMIT there’s so many good ones I can’t pick just 10.

Top 10 Favorites Overall:

…Though I feel like the impact it’s made on my top favorites may be a little deceptive, even if Zorua has finally toppled the champion four Generations in a row, Vulpix. If we were to look at more of a top 50 up to Gen 5, these newcomer faves would’ve had an absolute takeover.

Bottom 10 Least Favorites:

Gotta compress the monkeys and genies into one spot… cause they’d pretty much take up the entire Bottom 10. And even then, I think it says something when only half of these I’m not a very big fan of, and the other half are at least passable to kinda liking to me.

Bottom 10 Least Favorites Overall:

So they’ll make the slightest of dents here instead. And I’ll just lump them together since I mostly dislike them as collectives anyway.

The Cutest:

Pretty much all of these are gonna be some stiff competition and I’m slaying myself to come to a conclusion to. That said though, there’s no way Sewaddle and Joltik couldn’t have made it here. Just LOOK AT THEM.

The Coolest:

If some kick-ass monsters are what you’re after, I feel like Gen 5 definitely doesn’t get enough credit here. Again, it pains me to leave some out, like Genesect, Scolipede, Gigalith, and Archeops.

The Prettiest:

Wow, a whole house of pretty Pokemon too? Nice.

The Spookiest:

A good generation for spooks too! It sadly may not have the hugest variety but what is there is Halloweeny as hell and I love it. Even got an alien! Aliens are 200% underrated as Halloween monsters.

Most Creative:

God Gen 5 has so many Pokemon with fun and cool nuances to their designs. Scrafty to me is still a level of clever that comes pretty close to rivaling Shedinja.

Weirdest/Most Unique:

I even could’ve stuck quite a few I’ve already picked from above, like Beheeyem or Escavalier in here too. But fully and truly, Cryogonal is one weird as hell Pokemon. There’s actually nothing else like it in the game, I feel. What Pokemon fan would’ve asked for an ominously floating snowflake face that also turns out to be carnivorous??? It’s great.

Most Forgettable:

Yeah, mostly the common, early-game fodder Pokemon this time around. Especially since to one extent or another, their previous forms appeal to me just a little bit more.

Most Under-Appreciated:

Pshhhh, yeah, I’m sure Garbodor and Vanilluxe could be seen from a mile away. And yeah, by now they’ve developed their own niche of fans. But I still see them a lot, if not in the videos themselves, in the thumbnails of “Top 10 Worst/Least Creative Pokemon Designs” videos from Youtubers. (But we’ll let creatively bankrupt Gallade slide I guess)

And I’ll donate the rest of the space to Pokemon that just need to be noticed in general.

Summing up Gen 5 in 6 Pokemon:

God, that’s a tough one and you KNOW it, me. But I ultimately decided upon this. As big a variety of monsters as I could think of. Mainly because Gen 5’s sense of variety is insane. Probably at least partly due to there being so many, but still. There’s a Pokemon of all sorts of flavors, and many Pokemon for each flavor. Everybody, no matter what, should be able to find a handful to like in Gen 5. Even if you think Garbodor ruins the entire Generation on its own.

My Gen 5 Team:

Hoo boy, prepare yourselves cause this is the game I’ve easily replayed all the way through the most. But I’ll just cover the major playthroughs I did.

Shortly after the games launched in Japan, like a naughty person I… downloaded and played a ROM of it before the games were even out in the US. I was too friggin excited to play it! But here I kinda deliberately picked some Pokemon I didn’t think I’d be big on using in the main game so I could save the good stuff for when I play it for real. Including my least favorite Starter, obviously. I didn’t expect Leavanny and Krookodile to kick so much ass though.

And here is when I started to pick up my current mantra when it comes to picking out the team I’d like to use for a playthrough of a Pokemon game. I’ll pick out a handful I’ll like, (And if it’s the first playthrough of a new Generation, I’ll pick only new Pokemon. Not that it was difficult in the Generation with no old ones in it, of course, but Black and White inspired that rule.) and I’ll choose at least one Pokemon that’s unassuming and I wouldn’t be sure is good or not. It was Unfezant. Needless to say, bad stats and movepool matchup lead to it swiftly getting replaced by Zekrom as soon as the game asked me to. Heatmor’s still low-tier enough to consider it the unassuming pick right…?

But for real, this right here is probably one of my most memorable teams through a game to date. Unfezant aside, just about everyone kicked ass and took names. Gigalith especially. My Bertha wrecks house and I love her.

And then there’s my team for White 2. My unassuming Pokemon was Magnemite, but then it turned out Magnezone actually kicks a lot of ass. Probably partly what led to me falling in love with the thing.

Most Long Overdue Concepts and Creatures:

Galvantula’s on here just because it’s A. While not the first spider, the first spider that actually looks like a Spider. And B. While not the first spider, the first spider since Gen 2. You’d think spiders would be a much more common appearance in Pokemon!! Also missing was an ant Pokemon, Centipedes, Hermit Crabs, and flatfish. And a multi-headed dragon. Surprised we didn’t get one of those before.

Best Pokemon as Gen 1 Parallels:

Many of the Pokemon this Gen seeked out to recapture Gen 1’s magic touch, to a point where that was a deliberation outright stated in an interview about the game. I feel like this batch of 6 (7) do it best, in that they are a clear reference to previous Pokemon, but have enough of their own merit to stand on their own as well. Swoobat is almost like an anti-Golbat, Genesect is a cool way to “remake” Mewtwo, Sawk and Throh are Hitmonlee and Hitmonchan but a little more visually tied together. Garbodor is more or less the Muk of the Generation, representing physical waste vs water pollution. And Musharna is just a good example of how you can take something as specific as a dream-eating tapir and put different spins on it. Fun!

…Okay I’m bsing categories at this point just to make it last that tiny bit longer, sorry.

And… it saddens me a little bit, but that’s all that’s left to say about Gen 5. A fantastic Generation that’s gonna be really hard for a future Gen to top for me. None so far has done it yet, and of course we’ll have to wait and see if the rumblings of Gen 8 will triumph. But I digress, fret not! Not all is bad, because Gen 6 and 7 both give Gen 5 a fair amount of competition here. Next time, after the usual break, we’re KINDA gonna move into Gen 6. But we’ve got something else to cover briefly before we start Gen 6 for real.

[Archive]

Weirdest/Most Unique:

I even could’ve stuck quite a few I’ve already picked from above, like Beheeyem or Escavalier in here too. But fully and truly, Cryogonal is one weird as hell Pokemon. There’s actually nothing else like it in the game, I feel. What Pokemon fan would’ve asked for an ominously floating snowflake face that also turns out to be carnivorous??? It’s great.

Most Forgettable:

Yeah, mostly the common, early-game fodder Pokemon this time around. Especially since to one extent or another, their previous forms appeal to me just a little bit more.

Most Under-Appreciated:

Pshhhh, yeah, I’m sure Garbodor and Vanilluxe could be seen from a mile away. And yeah, by now they’ve developed their own niche of fans. But I still see them a lot, if not in the videos themselves, in the thumbnails of “Top 10 Worst/Least Creative Pokemon Designs” videos from Youtubers. (But we’ll let creatively bankrupt Gallade slide I guess)

And I’ll donate the rest of the space to Pokemon that just need to be noticed in general.

Summing up Gen 5 in 6 Pokemon:

God, that’s a tough one and you KNOW it, me. But I ultimately decided upon this. As big a variety of monsters as I could think of. Mainly because Gen 5’s sense of variety is insane. Probably at least partly due to there being so many, but still. There’s a Pokemon of all sorts of flavors, and many Pokemon for each flavor. Everybody, no matter what, should be able to find a handful to like in Gen 5. Even if you think Garbodor ruins the entire Generation on its own.

My Gen 5 Team:

Hoo boy, prepare yourselves cause this is the game I’ve easily replayed all the way through the most. But I’ll just cover the major playthroughs I did.

Shortly after the games launched in Japan, like a naughty person I… downloaded and played a ROM of it before the games were even out in the US. I was too friggin excited to play it! But here I kinda deliberately picked some Pokemon I didn’t think I’d be big on using in the main game so I could save the good stuff for when I play it for real. Including my least favorite Starter, obviously. I didn’t expect Leavanny and Krookodile to kick so much ass though.

And here is when I started to pick up my current mantra when it comes to picking out the team I’d like to use for a playthrough of a Pokemon game. I’ll pick out a handful I’ll like, (And if it’s the first playthrough of a new Generation, I’ll pick only new Pokemon. Not that it was difficult in the Generation with no old ones in it, of course, but Black and White inspired that rule.) and I’ll choose at least one Pokemon that’s unassuming and I wouldn’t be sure is good or not. It was Unfezant. Needless to say, bad stats and movepool matchup lead to it swiftly getting replaced by Zekrom as soon as the game asked me to. Heatmor’s still low-tier enough to consider it the unassuming pick right…?

But for real, this right here is probably one of my most memorable teams through a game to date. Unfezant aside, just about everyone kicked ass and took names. Gigalith especially. My Bertha wrecks house and I love her.

And then there’s my team for White 2. My unassuming Pokemon was Magnemite, but then it turned out Magnezone actually kicks a lot of ass. Probably partly what led to me falling in love with the thing.

Most Long Overdue Concepts and Creatures:

Galvantula’s on here just because it’s A. While not the first spider, the first spider that actually looks like a Spider. And B. While not the first spider, the first spider since Gen 2. You’d think spiders would be a much more common appearance in Pokemon!! Also missing was an ant Pokemon, Centipedes, Hermit Crabs, and flatfish. And a multi-headed dragon. Surprised we didn’t get one of those before.

Best Pokemon as Gen 1 Parallels:

Many of the Pokemon this Gen seeked out to recapture Gen 1’s magic touch, to a point where that was a deliberation outright stated in an interview about the game. I feel like this batch of 6 (7) do it best, in that they are a clear reference to previous Pokemon, but have enough of their own merit to stand on their own as well. Swoobat is almost like an anti-Golbat, Genesect is a cool way to “remake” Mewtwo, Sawk and Throh are Hitmonlee and Hitmonchan but a little more visually tied together. Garbodor is more or less the Muk of the Generation, representing physical waste vs water pollution. And Musharna is just a good example of how you can take something as specific as a dream-eating tapir and put different spins on it. Fun!

…Okay I’m bsing categories at this point just to make it last that tiny bit longer, sorry.

And… it saddens me a little bit, but that’s all that’s left to say about Gen 5. A fantastic Generation that’s gonna be really hard for a future Gen to top for me. None so far has done it yet, and of course we’ll have to wait and see if the rumblings of Gen 8 will triumph. But I digress, fret not! Not all is bad, because Gen 6 and 7 both give Gen 5 a fair amount of competition here. Next time, after the usual break, we’re KINDA gonna move into Gen 6. But we’ve got something else to cover briefly before we start Gen 6 for real.

[Archive]

summary: “ On Newmoon Island, Darkrai dreams. ” Dream Eater is a mature gameverse Pokemon RP with regular events and a...
caption:
“ On Newmoon Island, Darkrai dreams. ”

Dream Eater is a mature gameverse Pokemon RP with regular events and a heavy basis on themes of nightmares and shared dreaming. Something strange is happening across every Pokemon region, an unexplained phenomenon drawing people across the world into strange nightmares and dreamscapes – with each other. There’s been an effort to make a network of everyone experiencing the phenomenon, but whether any truths will be found is as of yet undetermined.

We are 18+, set on discord, and have modes for both para rp and ic chat. Come check out our pages for more info! 🌠🌙

    Home - Ask - Rules - Plot - Masterlist - Apply - Appcount
